href="/2014/05/20/us/us-to-charge-chinese-workers-with-cyberspying.html">398</a></span></div></span></li></ul></div></div><figure class="sizeMedium css-1d5j3k5" aria-label="media" role="group" data-testid="VideoBlock"><div class="css-1xb94ky"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Video</span><div><div class="css-n27z15" style="padding-bottom:56.25%"><div class="css-mm3pwi"><div style="height:0"><div class="css-vxcmzt"><div class="css-79elbk"><button type="button" aria-label="More sharing options ..." aria-expanded="false" class="css-125598s"></button></div></div></div><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000002888729/holder-announces-espionage-charges.html","description":"Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced charges against Chinese army personnel for hacking into American companies including Westinghouse, United States Steel and Alcoa.","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000002888729/holder-announces-espionage-charges.html","name":"Holder Announces Espionage Charges","thumbnailUrl":["https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/multimedia/holder-espionage-charges/holder-espionage-charges-videoSixteenByNine1050.jpg","https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/multimedia/holder-espionage-charges/holder-espionage-charges-superJumbo.jpg","https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/multimedia/holder-espionage-charges/holder-espionage-charges-square640.jpg"],"embedUrl":"https://www.nytimes.com/video/players/offsite/index.html?videoId=100000002888729","contentUrl":"http://vp.nyt.com/video/2014/05/19/28346_1_holder-espionage-charges_wg_240p.mp4","uploadDate":"2014-05-19T15:50:01.000Z","duration":"PT1M27S"}</script></div><div class="css-1cueeje" style="padding-bottom:56.25%;transition:opacity 300ms ease-in-out"><div class="css-1ihorw"><img src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/multimedia/holder-espionage-charges/holder-espionage-charges-videoSixteenByNine1050.jpg" alt="Video player loading"/></div><div class="css-ew1078"><div class="css-ptry2i"><div></div><div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-ktho12 e3rygrp0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0" data-testid="video-summary">Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced charges against Chinese army personnel for hacking into American companies including Westinghouse, United States Steel and Alcoa.</span><span class="css-cch8ym"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Credit</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Charles Dharapak/Associated Press</span></span></span></figcaption></figure><div data-testid="byline-timestamp" class="css-xt80pu eakwutd0"><div class="css-p6m5rf"><div class="byline-container css-1e2jphy epjyd6m2"><div class="css-233int epjyd6m1"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/by/michael-s-schmidt" class="css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Michael S. Schmidt</a> and <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/by/david-e-sanger" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">David E. Sanger</a></p><div class="css-1gqes1i epjyd6m0"></div></div></div><ul class="css-1cgskve epjyd6m4"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m3"><time class="css-1uc6ajg e16638kd0" dateTime="2014-05-19T08:13:34-04:00">May 19, 2014</time></li></ul></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">WASHINGTON — In the Obama administration’s most direct confrontation with China over its theft of corporate secrets, the Justice Department on Monday unsealed an indictment of five members of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army and charged them with hacking into the networks of Westinghouse Electric, the United States Steel Corporation and other companies. </p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The indictment named members of Unit 61398, which was publicly identified last year as the Shanghai-based cyberunit of the People’s Liberation Army, including its best-known hackers known online by the noms de guerre “UglyGorilla” and “KandyGoo.” </p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The F.B.I. and American intelligence agencies electronically tracked the activities of the hackers, one official said, and “put them inside the Datong Road headquarters” of the cyberunit, a heavily guarded 12-floor military tower near the Shanghai airport. </p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The move by the Justice Department was almost certainly symbolic since there is virtually no chance that the Chinese would turn over the five People’s Liberation Army members named in the indictment. </p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-1"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Since 2006, and as recently as last month, the indictment alleged, the hacking unit invaded the networks of American corporate targets, systematically copying their emails and, in some cases, infecting their computers with malware. </p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-3"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><img alt="" class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/world/americas/20CYBER2/20CYBER2-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/world/americas/20CYBER2/20CYBER2-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/world/americas/20CYBER2/20CYBER2-jumbo-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/19/world/americas/20CYBER2/20CYBER2-superJumbo-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" uri="nyt://image/9baa2d38-c850-5fbf-a06e-d7103613a044" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">The Justice Department sought to shame officials with the People&rsquo;s Liberation Army by displaying wanted posters on Monday.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Charles Dharapak/Associated Press</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div data-testid="InteractiveBlock-4"><div class="css-1sk8wv4" data-testid="interactive-block"><a class="css-1f0en3d" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/05/19/us/20cyber.html"><div class="css-1fnp0wc"><img alt="" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/05/20/us/20cyber-memo/20cyber-memo-thumbLarge.jpg"/></div><div class="css-1g3u91s"><h2 class="css-1a9yvhp">Indictment Memorandum</h2><p class="css-vop5d5">The Justice Department said that the men were indicted on May 1 by a federal grand jury in Pennsylvania and charged with conspiring to commit computer fraud and accessing a computer without authorization for the purpose of commercial advantage.</p></div></a></div></div><div data-testid="Optimistic-5"><div class="css-1336jj"><div class="css-121kum4"><div class="css-171quhb"></div><div class="css-asuuk5"><noscript><div class="css-7axq9l" data-testid="optimistic-truncator-noscript"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true" class="css-1b5b8u1"><path fill="currentColor" fill-rule="evenodd" d="M2.5 12a9.5 9.5 0 1 1 19 0 9.5 9.5 0 0 1-19 0Zm8.5 1.75v-7.5h2v7.5h-2Zm0 2v2h2v-2h-2Z" clip-rule="evenodd"></path></svg><div data-testid="optimistic-truncator-noscript-message" class="css-6yo1no"><p class="css-3kpklk">We are having trouble retrieving the article content.</p><p class="css-3kpklk">Please enable JavaScript in your browser settings.</p></div></div></noscript><div class="css-1dv1kvn" id="optimistic-truncator-a11y" tabindex="-1"><hr/><p>Thank you for your patience while we verify access. of an editing error, an earlier version of this article attributed remarks incorrectly to Attorney General Eric H. Holder. It was John Carlin, an assistant Attorney general for national security — not by Mr. Holder — who alleged that members of unit 61398 conspired to hack into computers of six United States victims and gave examples of damage done by the Chinese hackers."}],"textAlign":"DEFAULT"}],"text":"Because of an editing error, an earlier version of this article attributed remarks incorrectly to Attorney General Eric H. Holder.
